title: Valley of Flowers National Park
short_description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site in the Himalayas, famous for its endemic alpine flowers and stunning natural beauty.
long_description: Valley of Flowers National Park is an Indian national park, located in North Chamoli, in the state of Uttarakhand and is known for its meadows of endemic alpine flowers and the variety of flora. This richly diverse area is also home to rare and endangered animals, including the Asiatic black bear, snow leopard, musk deer and blue sheep. The gentle landscape of the Valley of Flowers National Park complements the rugged mountain wilderness of Nanda Devi National Park to the east. Together, they encompass a unique transition zone between the mountain ranges of the Zanskar and Great Himalaya.
wildlife_significance: UNESCO World Heritage Site. Rich diversity of endemic alpine flora.
guides_and_tips: It's a steep trek. Hiring a pony/doli from Govindghat to Ghangaria is possible, but inside the valley, you must walk. Rain gear is essential.
how_to_reach: By Air: Dehradun (295 km). By Rail: Rishikesh (276 km). By Road: Drive to Govindghat, then trek 14 km to Ghangaria.
permits_and_fees: Permits issued at Ghangaria check post. Valid for 3 days.
conservation_notes: Camping inside the valley is strictly prohibited. You must return to Ghangaria by sunset.
sample_itinerary: Day 1: Drive Rishikesh to Govindghat. Day 2: Trek to Ghangaria (14 km). Day 3: Trek to Valley of Flowers (4 km one way). Return to Ghangaria. Day 4: Trek to Hemkund Sahib (Optional). Day 5: Trek down and drive back.
safety_tips: High altitude. Acclimatize well. Landslides common in monsoon.

opening_hours.time_notes: Entry closes at 2 PM. Visitors must exit by 5 PM.

operating_season.season_notes: Park usually opens 1st June and closes 31st October.

pricing_metadata.disclaimer: Porter/Pony rates are fixed by union.
